quizzes.title: Solar System Basics
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge about the planets, moons, and other celestial bodies in our solar system.

questionsData.question: Which planet is known as the Red Planet?
questionsData.explanation: Mars is called the Red Planet due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface.

questionsData.question: How many moons does Jupiter have?
questionsData.explanation: Jupiter has 95 confirmed moons, with the four largest being Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.

questionsData.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questionsData.explanation: Jupiter is the largest planet, with a mass greater than all other planets combined.

questionsData.question: Which planet has the most eccentric orbit?
questionsData.explanation: Mercury has the most eccentric orbit of the eight planets.

questionsData.question: What is the hottest planet in our solar system?
questionsData.explanation: Venus is the hottest planet due to its thick atmosphere causing a runaway greenhouse effect.

questionsData.question: Which planet has the most rings?
questionsData.explanation: Saturn has the most extensive ring system made of ice and rock.

questionsData.question: Which planet has the shortest day?
questionsData.explanation: Jupiter has a very short day ‚Äî it completes a rotation in about 10 hours.

questionsData.question: Which planet rotates on its side?
questionsData.explanation: Uranus rotates nearly sideways, with an axial tilt of 98 degrees.

questionsData.question: Which two planets do not have moons?
questionsData.explanation: Mercury and Venus are the only two planets without moons.

questionsData.question: Which planet is farthest from the Sun?
questionsData.explanation: Neptune is currently the farthest planet from the Sun in our solar system.

questionsData.question: Which planet has the strongest gravity?
questionsData.explanation: Jupiter‚Äôs massive size gives it the strongest gravity of any planet.

questionsData.question: What is the asteroid belt?
options: A region with many asteroids between Mars and Jupiter
questionsData.explanation: The asteroid belt lies between Mars and Jupiter and contains many rocky bodies.

questionsData.question: What causes a planet to be considered 'terrestrial'?
questionsData.explanation: Terrestrial planets are primarily rocky, like Earth, Mars, Venus, and Mercury.

questionsData.question: Which planet is famous for its Great Red Spot?
questionsData.explanation: The Great Red Spot is a giant storm on Jupiter.

questionsData.question: Which planet has seasons like Earth?
questionsData.explanation: Mars has a similar axial tilt to Earth, giving it seasons.

questionsData.question: Which planet is closest in size to Earth?
questionsData.explanation: Venus is often called Earth‚Äôs twin due to its similar size and composition.

questionsData.question: What is a dwarf planet?
options: A planet outside the solar system
A celestial body that orbits the Sun but hasn't cleared its orbit
questionsData.explanation: Dwarf planets like Pluto orbit the Sun but don‚Äôt clear their orbital path.

questionsData.question: What is the Kuiper Belt?
options: A region beyond Neptune with icy bodies
questionsData.explanation: The Kuiper Belt contains icy objects and dwarf planets beyond Neptune.

questionsData.question: Which planet has the tallest volcano?
questionsData.explanation: Olympus Mons on Mars is the tallest known volcano in the solar system.

questionsData.question: What is the name of Earth's Moon?
questionsData.explanation: The official name of Earth's moon is 'Luna', derived from Latin.

quizzes.title: Space Exploration
quizzes.description: Learn about historic space missions, astronauts, and the future of space exploration.

questionsData.question: Who was the first human in space?
questionsData.explanation: Yuri Gagarin became the first human in space on April 12, 1961.

questionsData.question: Which mission first landed humans on the Moon?
questionsData.explanation: Apollo 11 successfully landed Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the Moon in 1969.

questionsData.question: What was the first artificial satellite?
questionsData.explanation: Sputnik 1 was launched by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957.

questionsData.question: Which space agency operates the James Webb Space Telescope?
questionsData.explanation: NASA operates JWST in collaboration with ESA and CSA.

questionsData.question: What is the International Space Station's orbital speed?
questionsData.explanation: The ISS orbits Earth at approximately 17,500 mph (28,000 km/h).

questionsData.question: Which space shuttle was the first to go into space?
questionsData.explanation: Columbia was the first space shuttle to fly in space in 1981.

questionsData.question: What is SpaceX's reusable rocket called?
questionsData.explanation: Falcon 9 is a reusable two-stage rocket developed by SpaceX.

questionsData.question: Who was the first American woman in space?
questionsData.explanation: Sally Ride flew aboard the Challenger in 1983 as the first American woman in space.

questionsData.question: Which country was the first to land a rover on Mars?
questionsData.explanation: The USA's Viking 1 lander became the first to successfully operate on Mars in 1976.

questionsData.question: What was the name of the Mars rover that sang 'Happy Birthday' to itself?
questionsData.explanation: NASA's Curiosity rover played 'Happy Birthday' to itself on Mars in 2013.

questionsData.question: Which private company first launched astronauts to the ISS?
questionsData.explanation: SpaceX launched NASA astronauts to the ISS aboard Crew Dragon in 2020.

questionsData.question: Which mission ended the Apollo program?
questionsData.explanation: Apollo 17, launched in 1972, was the final mission of NASA's Apollo lunar program.

questionsData.question: Which astronaut spent the longest single mission in space?
questionsData.explanation: Valeri Polyakov spent 437 days aboard the Mir space station from 1994‚Äì1995.

questionsData.question: Which spacecraft traveled the farthest from Earth?
questionsData.explanation: Voyager 1, launched in 1977, is the most distant human-made object from Earth.

questionsData.question: What is the name of NASA‚Äôs new Moon mission program?
questionsData.explanation: Artemis is NASA‚Äôs program to return humans to the Moon and beyond.

questionsData.question: Which Mars rover succeeded Opportunity and landed in 2021?
questionsData.explanation: NASA‚Äôs Perseverance rover landed on Mars in February 2021 to search for signs of ancient life.

questionsData.question: Which country was the first to land on the far side of the Moon?
questionsData.explanation: China‚Äôs Chang‚Äôe 4 mission landed on the Moon's far side in 2019 ‚Äî a world first.

questionsData.question: What is the name of the space probe that studied Pluto in 2015?
questionsData.explanation: NASA‚Äôs New Horizons flew by Pluto in 2015, sending back detailed images of the dwarf planet.

questionsData.question: Which female astronaut holds the record for most spacewalks?
questionsData.explanation: Peggy Whitson completed 10 spacewalks ‚Äî the most by any woman in history.

questionsData.question: What is NASA‚Äôs space capsule designed to carry astronauts beyond low Earth orbit?
questionsData.explanation: Orion is NASA‚Äôs deep-space capsule designed for missions to the Moon and Mars under the Artemis program.

quizzes.title: Deep Space
quizzes.description: Explore galaxies, black holes, nebulae, and the mysteries of the distant universe.

questionsData.question: What is the closest star to our solar system?
questionsData.explanation: Proxima Centauri is the closest star to our solar system at 4.24 light-years away.

questionsData.question: What type of galaxy is the Milky Way?
questionsData.explanation: The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy with several spiral arms.

questionsData.question: What is a supernova?
questionsData.explanation: A supernova is the explosive death of a massive star at the end of its life cycle.

questionsData.question: What is the event horizon?
questionsData.explanation: The event horizon is the boundary around a black hole beyond which nothing can escape.

questionsData.question: How old is the universe approximately?
questionsData.explanation: The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old based on cosmic microwave background measurements.

questionsData.question: What is a black hole?
options: A collapsed star with immense gravity
questionsData.explanation: A black hole is a collapsed star whose gravity is so strong that not even light can escape.

questionsData.question: What is dark matter?
options: Invisible matter that makes up most of the universe's mass
questionsData.explanation: Dark matter is invisible and makes up about 27% of the universe's mass-energy content.

questionsData.question: Which telescope discovered the first exoplanets?
questionsData.explanation: NASA‚Äôs Kepler telescope discovered thousands of exoplanets by detecting dips in starlight.

questionsData.question: What is a quasar?
options: A supermassive black hole emitting enormous energy
questionsData.explanation: Quasars are extremely bright centers of distant galaxies powered by supermassive black holes.

questionsData.question: What does the cosmic microwave background represent?
questionsData.explanation: The CMB is leftover radiation from the Big Bang, giving clues about the early universe.

questionsData.question: What is the fate of most massive stars?
questionsData.explanation: Massive stars often end their life cycle in a supernova explosion.

questionsData.question: Which galaxy is expected to collide with the Milky Way?
questionsData.explanation: The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way in about 4.5 billion years.

questionsData.question: What is the most abundant element in the universe?
questionsData.explanation: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, making up about 75% of all matter.

questionsData.question: How are distances to stars typically measured?
questionsData.explanation: Parallax involves observing the apparent motion of a star against distant background stars as Earth orbits the Sun.

questionsData.question: What does redshift indicate about a galaxy?
questionsData.explanation: Redshift means the galaxy‚Äôs light is stretched, indicating it‚Äôs moving away due to universe expansion.

questionsData.question: What is a neutron star?
options: The dense core left after a supernova
questionsData.explanation: A neutron star is the collapsed core of a massive star that exploded as a supernova.

questionsData.question: What are gravitational waves?
options: Ripples in spacetime from cosmic events
questionsData.explanation: Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime caused by massive objects like merging black holes.

questionsData.question: Which mission studies black holes using X-rays?
questionsData.explanation: NASA‚Äôs Chandra X-ray Observatory observes high-energy regions like black holes and neutron stars.

questionsData.question: What is the name of the largest known galaxy?
questionsData.explanation: IC 1101 is one of the largest known galaxies, stretching over 6 million light-years across.

questionsData.question: What is a light-year?
options: Time it takes for light to fade
Distance light travels in one year
questionsData.explanation: A light-year is a unit of distance‚Äîhow far light travels in one Earth year (about 5.88 trillion miles).

learningCards.title: Get to Know: Black Holes
learningCards.description: Discover the fascinating physics behind these cosmic phenomena and how they affect spacetime.

learningCards.title: Get to Know: Exoplanets
learningCards.description: Learn about planets beyond our solar system and the search for potentially habitable worlds.

learningCards.title: Get to Know: Space Weather
learningCards.description: Understand solar flares, cosmic rays, and how space weather affects Earth and astronauts.
